title: Quiz 2: August 2012 Licensure Exam
description: August 2012 Licensure Examination. Covers Community Diagnosis, Immunization, Communicable Diseases, and Health Management.

questions.question: Community diagnosis is carried out:

options.text: With active participation of members of the community
With active participation of the leaders in the community
With active participation of health workers only
By strictly looking at medical problems

questions.explanation: Community diagnosis requires the full involvement of the community in identifying their own health problems, setting priorities, and planning solutions (Primary Health Care principle).
questions.hint: PHC emphasizes 'with' the people, not just 'for' the people.

questions.question: Incidence rate:

options.text: Is used to record protracted diseases
Shows the magnitude/burden of disease in the community
Is useful for planning and administration of health care services
Shows the rate of development of disease in the community

questions.explanation: Incidence measures the number of NEW cases occurring in a population over a period, reflecting the rate of development/risk. Prevalence measures the burden.
questions.hint: Incidence = New cases (development rate).

questions.question: The common side effect a nurse should counsel a mother for after giving her child pneumococcal vaccine is:

options.text: Blood clot at the site of injection

questions.explanation: Common side effects of PCV include injection site reactions, fever, irritability, drowsiness, and loss of appetite.
questions.hint: The child may not want to eat.

questions.question: A special consideration for immunocompromised person regarding immunization is that:

options.text: Asymptomatic HIV infected children should not receive BCG vaccine
Live vaccines can safely be given to persons on corticosteroid therapy
Asymptomatic children infected with HIV should receive all standard KEPI vaccines
Pentavalent vaccine can be administered to a child with neurologic disease so long as they are monitored closely

questions.explanation: Asymptomatic HIV+ children should receive all standard vaccines, including BCG. Only symptomatic HIV is a contraindication for BCG/Yellow Fever (live vaccines).
questions.hint: If they show no symptoms, treat them normally regarding vaccines.

questions.question: When constructing a septic tank for 15 users, the recommended dimensions are:
questions.explanation: For 15 users, a volume of ~2.7 cubic meters (3.0m x 0.6m x 1.5m) is appropriate to handle the wastewater load with sufficient retention time.
questions.hint: 3 meters long is the standard recommendation for this size.

questions.question: A typical case of severe cholera presents with:

options.text: High fever with severe abdominal cramps
Decreased urine production preceding profuse watery stool

questions.explanation: The hallmark of cholera is sudden, painless, profuse 'rice-water' diarrhea, which typically starts before vomiting occurs.
questions.hint: Diarrhea comes first and is very watery.

questions.question: Amoebic dysentery:

options.text: Is spread by infected persons who pass infective trophozoites in feaces
May present with bottle shaped ulcers on the intestinal wall

questions.explanation: Entamoeba histolytica invades the mucosa creating characteristic flask-shaped (bottle-shaped) ulcers. It is spread by cysts, not trophozoites (which die outside).
questions.hint: Think about the shape of the ulcer.

questions.question: A child who presents with widening of the wrists, recurrent pneumonia and has prominent costo-chrondral joints is likely to have:
questions.explanation: These are classic signs of Rickets (Vitamin D deficiency): Widened wrists, Rachitic Rosary (costo-chondral joints), and respiratory susceptibility.
questions.hint: Rickets affects bones and immunity.

questions.question: Measurement of the mid upper arm circumference is performed:

options.text: When the child's age is under one year
With or without a weighing scale
As a screening method for in-patients

questions.explanation: MUAC is a rapid screening tool for malnutrition used primarily in community field surveys for children 6-59 months.
questions.hint: It is a field tool.

questions.question: Drugs that are known to reduce the efficacy of hormonal contraceptives are:
questions.explanation: Rifampicin and Phenytoin are liver enzyme inducers that increase the metabolism of hormonal contraceptives, reducing their effectiveness.
questions.hint: One is an anti-TB drug, the other is an anti-convulsant.

questions.question: The WHO recommended treatment of uncomplicated Neisseria gonorrhoea is:

options.text: Benzyl penicillin 3g intramuscularly as a single dose
Ofloxacin 400 mg orally as a single dose
Ceftriaxone 250 mg intramuscularly as a single dose
Azithromycin 1g orally as a single dose

questions.explanation: Due to resistance, Ceftriaxone (IM) is the standard treatment. Azithromycin is often added for Chlamydia coverage.
questions.hint: It is an injectable Cephalosporin.

questions.question: When managing accidental exposure to body fluids (needle prick), arrange the actions in the correct sequence:

items.text: Wash the wound under running water with soap

questions.explanation: First Aid (Wash) -> Assessment (Test) -> Prophylaxis (Meds).
questions.hint: Wash first.

questions.question: Controlling function in management involves:

options.text: Determining philosophy and goals, managing action

questions.explanation: Controlling involves monitoring performance and taking corrective action (e.g., appraisal, QM). Staffing is C, Organizing is D.
questions.hint: Checking if things are going as planned.

questions.question: After Alma Ata Declaration, three (3) elements of primary health that were added in Kenya are:

options.text: Mental health, HIV and AIDs, Dental health
Mental health, provision of essential drugs, HIV and AIDs
Mental health, provision of essential drugs, immunization

questions.explanation: Kenya expanded the original 8 elements to include Mental Health, Dental Health, and HIV/AIDS control.
questions.hint: HIV/AIDS is a major addition.

questions.question: Arrange community participation in organization of health services in ascending order (Passive to Active):
questions.explanation: The ladder of participation goes from Information (passive) -> Consultation -> Discussion -> Control (active).
questions.hint: Start with just being told, end with being in charge.

questions.question: Specific functions of school health include:

options.text: Conducting special screening programs, treatment of cases by teachers...
Determining health status... continuously appraising changes...
Continuously appraising changes in each child, case management of a sick child

questions.explanation: School health involves continuous appraisal (screening/monitoring) and case management (treatment/referral) of sick children.
questions.hint: It involves both monitoring changes and treating sickness.

questions.question: Primary prevention of occupational health care hazards includes:

options.text: Emphasis on first aid to minimize complications
Dealing with substances inhaled... because of poor attitudes
General screening of non occupational illness before a person is hired
Screening of the working environment to check that recommended preventive measures are put in place

questions.explanation: Primary prevention aims to stop the hazard before it reaches the worker. Screening the environment ensures controls are in place.
questions.hint: Check the environment, not just the person.

questions.question: A child aged 9 â€“ 12 months is able to:

options.text: Stand without assistance and throw balls
Walk without support and grasp small objects with thumb and fingers
Enjoy imitation and take objects out of a container
Walk and can say some sentences

questions.explanation: At 9-12 months, children develop pincer grasp, object permanence (containers), and imitation skills.
questions.hint: Walking without support usually happens after 12 months.

questions.question: Evaluate the following statements. Statement A: 'Naturalistic trend assumes illness is cured by a supernatural being.' Statement B: 'In the personalistic trend, treatment is related to the cause of misfortune.'

options.text: Statement A is True, B is False
Statement A is False, B is True

questions.explanation: Statement A is False: Naturalistic refers to impersonal causes (cold/heat). Supernatural cures belong to Personalistic. Statement B is True: Personalistic systems treat the 'Who' or 'Why' (cause of misfortune/spirit).
questions.hint: Naturalistic = Nature/Balance. Personalistic = Person/Spirit.

questions.question: Match the disease with the correct clinical sign description:
questions.explanation: Measles presents with Cough, Coryza, Conjunctivitis and Koplik's spots. Rubella does not have Koplik's spots.
questions.hint: Measles has the 3 Cs.

questions.question: Select the universal precautions for HIV prevention among health workers: (Select all that apply)

options.text: Safe disposal of sharps in safety boxes
Safe management of spills with chlorine

questions.explanation: Key precautions include hand washing, PPE, NEVER recapping needles, safe sharps disposal, and spill management.
questions.hint: Never recap needles.

questions.question: Which of the following are characteristics of culture? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Culture is Learned, Shared, Dynamic, Symbolic, Integrated, and Adaptive.
questions.hint: It is not static; it changes over time.

questions.question: Select the essential components of palliative care nursing: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Palliative care focuses on relief of suffering (pain/symptoms), psychosocial/spiritual support, and end-of-life care, not cure.
questions.hint: Focus on comfort and support, not cure.

questions.question: Arrange the phases of the disaster management cycle in logical order:
questions.explanation: The cycle moves from Prevention -> Preparedness (Before), Response (During), to Recovery/Reconstruction (After).
questions.hint: Prepare before you Respond.

questions.question: Select the socio-economic effects of malaria to a country: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Malaria causes economic loss through absenteeism, treatment costs, and reduced tourism.
questions.hint: It drains money and time.

questions.question: Ways by which transmission of a communicable disease can be interrupted include: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Interruption strategies target the agent, host, or environment (e.g., vaccination, vector control, treatment).
questions.hint: Break the chain of infection.

questions.question: Arrange the lifecycle of Wuchereria Bancrofti (Filariasis) in order:

items.text: Larvae migrate to lymphatics and mature
Larvae develop to L3 in mosquito

questions.explanation: Mosquito injects larvae -> Larvae go to lymph -> Adults produce microfilariae -> Mosquito takes them up -> Development in mosquito.
questions.hint: Mosquito to Human to Mosquito.

questions.question: Select the obstacles encountered in implementation of inter-sectoral collaboration: (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Obstacles include lack of money, different goals, poor communication, and protecting one's own territory (turf wars).
questions.hint: Why don't different departments work well together?

questions.question: Arrange the steps in investigating a Polio outbreak:
questions.explanation: Confirm/Verify -> Notify -> Search for more -> Analyze -> Control.
questions.hint: First make sure it IS polio.

questions.question: Match the Nursing Care Delivery Model to its description:

pairs.right: RN leads a group of staff to care for a group of patients
One nurse has 24hr responsibility for patient care plan
One nurse provides total care for one patient/shift (ICU)

questions.explanation: Functional = Tasks. Team = Group led by leader. Primary = 24hr responsibility. Case = Total care.
questions.hint: Functional is about tasks. Primary is about the patient.
